posts.cooked:
I was doing some Android development the other day and was enlisting the help of my spouse to test the app, so I thought I would just quickly send the .apk from my desktop via Signal, but no! ‚ÄúAttachment type not allowed for security reasons‚Äù. Looking at the Signal-Desktop source, it seems there is an entire list of extensions that are considered ‚Äúdangerous‚Äù:

github.com

signalapp/Signal-Desktop/blob/0850dc368a044c8894086ed282380743627d67d5/ts/util/isFileDangerous.ts#L2


      
    
          
  1. // tslint:disable-next-line max-line-length
    2. 
          
  2. const DANGEROUS_FILE_TYPES = /\.(ADE|ADP|APK|BAT|CHM|CMD|COM|CPL|DLL|DMG|EXE|HTA|INS|ISP|JAR|JS|JSE|LIB|LNK|MDE|MSC|MSI|MSP|MST|NSH|PIF|SCR|SCT|SHB|SYS|VB|VBE|VBS|VXD|WSC|WSF|WSH|CAB)$/i;
    3. 
          
  3. 
          
  4. export function isFileDangerous(fileName: string): boolean {
    5. 
          
  5.   return DANGEROUS_FILE_TYPES.test(fileName);
    6. 
          
  6. }
    7.

Of course, this is easily defeated by changing the .apk to .txt and renaming it back to .apk on the phone (or putting it in a .zip), but it‚Äôs always annoying when you have to do that. Additionally, Signal-Android doesn‚Äôt seem to have any kind of filtering based on file extension unless I‚Äôm missing something, so it‚Äôs possible to send the ‚Äúdangerous‚Äù files there, but a recipient using Signal-Desktop won‚Äôt be able to download them.

I would like to be able to send any type of file without having to ‚Äúfool‚Äù the Signal client. I understand that there is some aspect of protecting less techy people from themselves, but could it at least be implemented as a warning of ‚ÄúThis file is potentially dangerous‚Äù with an option to download anyway?

It also doesn‚Äôt make sense that the desktop client blocks APK‚Äôs, which are for Android, while the Android client is completely okay with them‚Ä¶

Bump. Additionally, I would like to know the reasoning behind the decision to block these extensions. Where do we draw the line? The same is happening more excessively for emails.

threatpost.com

Microsoft Blacklists Dozens of New File Extensions in Outlook

In total, Microsoft has now blocked 142 file extensions that it deems as at risk or that are typically sent as malicious attachments in emails.

Don‚Äôt understand me wrong, I do see the harm of sending potentially self executing vulnerabilities. But as a developer (and security researcher especially!) it gets harder to send files to workmates. I just wonder if there isn‚Äôt a better way of dealing with the threat?

Reason for the bump: Tried to send an apk to myself but couldn‚Äôt.

link_counts.title: Microsoft Blacklists Dozens of New File Extensions in Outlook | Threatpost

posts.name: River~~
posts.cooked:
I don‚Äôt the devs reasoning, but I can tell you why I think they are wise to do this, and why I would regret any change.

The malicious software is often opened automatically, or semi-automatically by a user sideloading a file without stopping to think. This message alerts the user that they are openng a potential security loophole. The naive user will therefore not go ahead, improving security. The wizardly user will know how to circumvent the block by renaming the file: OK it is more work, but the extra work gives enough time to think ‚Äúshould I be doing this‚Äù.

So I hope the feature is retained

I just dont think in all or nothing categories. Maybe there is another way to still prevent users initial response to open a malicious file. For example, the ‚Äúextra work‚Äù could also be achieved with sending a file without any extension. And the user have to provide the correct extension when s/he receives the file. Sure it can still be exploited by a malicious actor, but again this is just giving users enough time to reconsider their actions.

(or an exception for local file transfers within the same network. Also, if the devices are indeed in the same network an additional feature would be to not use the Signal server at all for transfer. Realizing, that this is most likely too much work for such an edge case and OS solutions may already exist)

posts.name: ‚ö†Ô∏è abandoned account ‚ö†Ô∏è
posts.cooked:
I don‚Äôt know if signal devs had that in mind at that moment, but ‚ÄúThere are no power users.‚Äù :

  1. There are no power users. The idea that some users ‚Äúunderstand‚Äù concepts better than others has proven to be, for the most part, false. If anything, ‚Äúpower users‚Äù are more dangerous than the rest, and we should avoid exposing dangerous functionality to them.

see Development Ideology

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked: Strange to block apk on desktop (where it can‚Äôt be installed directly anyway) and not on Android.

I just stumbled upon that. To add to the discussion: does it make sense to apply this filter to ‚ÄòNote to Self‚Äô?

I find it especially weird to block apk on desktop, but not on Android, where they can actually be damaging, as mentioned in the first post. At least the behaviors should be consistent.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: I would request to at least stop blocking attachments by type on note to self. Surly if someone sends an executable to themselves they have already foreseen the risk.
This. And for actual people it could be reworked so that anyone can, if they want, disable this kind of ‚Äúprotection‚Äù for themselves and receive such messages.

The only ‚Äúproblem‚Äù there is that then they‚Äôd have to implement blocking when forwarding so that you couldn‚Äôt just work around it by sending to Note To Self first, then forwarding the message. They really should just remove it entirely, since there isn‚Äôt any blocking in the mobile apps anyway.

Andrewsky:

it could be reworked so that anyone can, if they want, disable this kind of ‚Äúprotection‚Äù for themselves and receive such messages.

That would mean they would have to implementing as blocking on the receiving side, but there is no way to know what an attachment is until you have received the message, downloaded it, and decrypted it, so it‚Äôs not ideal.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
Herohtar:

The only ‚Äúproblem‚Äù there is that then they‚Äôd have to implement blocking when forwarding so that you couldn‚Äôt just work around it by sending to Note To Self first, then forwarding the message.

I would not mind if they took that approach, seems like a reasonable compromise between protecting people and allowing you to send executables to yourself. A simple toast ‚ÄúFor security reasons you can‚Äôt forward this filetype‚Äù would suffice.

Currently, the desktop companion for Signal disallows uploading many files types (apk, exe, js, etc), while the mobile app does not care about the file type at all. Additionally, the officially recognized workaround is to zip up the files before sending them.

I believe this feature does little, if anything, to deter any harmful behavior in the real world, and the workaround undermines the purpose of the security restriction as well. Additionally, the mobile app easily circumvents this. A pull request was made that implements this feature in it‚Äôs entirety but it was rejected with little explanation.

I would suggest there should at least be an opt-out toggle in the settings to allow uploading any file type, or the restriction removed entirely.

link_counts.title: Signal should allow file attachments of any type ¬∑ Issue #3849 ¬∑ signalapp/Signal-Desktop ¬∑ GitHub
Allow file attachments of any type by FXZFun ¬∑ Pull Request #6939 ¬∑ signalapp/Signal-Desktop ¬∑ GitHub

posts.name: TheCarpetMerchant
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôd be happy with an opt-in (give a warning message when trying to send a ‚Äúdangerous file‚Äù and allow doing it if the user accepts).
What I‚Äôm not happy with is the complete lack of explanation regarding why this isn‚Äôt allowed ? If it‚Äôs just ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt have the time to review‚Äù or some other external factors that‚Äôs fine, but giving no explanation is not fine.
